episodeTitle: To the New World! Heading for the Ultimate Sea!
description: The Straw Hat Pirates venture into the New World. During a deep-sea fishing expedition, the crew gets caught in a dangerous White Strom whirlpool but is saved by a pod of Island Whales when Brook plays Binks' Sake. They emerge into the treacherous waters of the New World.

events.title: Nami's Bath Scene
events.description: As the crew prepares for their journey into the New World, Nami takes a shower below deck. Sanji and Brook attempt to peek on her but are deterred. This scene showcases the crew's relaxed dynamics before entering the dangerous New World.
events.significance: Establishes the calm before the storm atmosphere and provides comedic relief before the crew faces the New World's dangers.

events.title: Deep Sea Fishing Competition Begins
events.description: Luffy, Zoro, and Usopp engage in a deep-sea fishing competition to catch food for the crew. They aim to catch the giant fish swimming in the depths below the Thousand Sunny.
events.significance: Demonstrates the crew's preparation for the New World journey and showcases their post-timeskip teamwork and upgraded abilities.

quotes.text: Let's catch some deep sea fish to eat!
quotes.speaker: Luffy

events.title: Usopp Reveals Hokaku Boshi
events.description: Usopp demonstrates his new post-timeskip fishing technique, Hokaku Boshi, using an upgraded slingshot larger than his Kuro Kabuto to hook and reel in giant deep-sea fish.
events.significance: Shows Usopp's growth during the two-year timeskip and his enhanced equipment and techniques.

quotes.speaker: Usopp
quotes.context: Usopp using his new fishing technique

events.title: Fish Eating Fish Escalation
events.description: After successfully hooking a large deep-sea fish, the crew watches as it is eaten by a progressively larger series of predators. Each fish that appears is consumed by an even bigger creature in a comedic escalation.
events.significance: Foreshadows the dangerous nature of the New World where even the wildlife operates on a scale of survival of the fittest.

events.title: Zoro's 360 Pound Cannon
events.description: Zoro demonstrates his upgraded post-timeskip sword technique, the 360 Pound Cannon, to kill the massive final fish in the chain. This is an enhanced version of his previous 108 Pound Cannon technique.
events.significance: Showcases Zoro's significant power increase after the two-year training with Mihawk, demonstrating the crew's readiness for the New World.

quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro using his upgraded technique to kill the giant fish

events.title: White Strom Encounter
events.description: Due to the extra weight of the massive fish, the Thousand Sunny is pulled into a White Strom, a gigantic white whirlpool that appears without warning on the sea floor. Robin warns the crew that ships caught in it are usually found days later with no crew aboard.
events.significance: Introduces one of the New World's natural dangers and creates a life-threatening situation that tests the crew's ability to handle the unpredictable hazards of the new sea.

quotes.text: It's not a sea snake, it's a White Strom! A gigantic white whirlpool that resembles a dragon which appears without warning on the sea floor!
quotes.speaker: Robin
quotes.context: Robin explaining the danger they're in

events.title: Nami's Shower Tempo
events.description: During the White Strom crisis, Nami demonstrates her new post-timeskip weather ability called Shower Tempo while coordinating the crew's response to the whirlpool.
events.significance: Shows Nami's enhanced meteorological skills and leadership after training with the Weather Wizards on Weatheria.

events.title: Island Whales Appear
events.description: A pod of Island Whales suddenly appears and blocks the White Strom's current. The massive creatures surround the Thousand Sunny, saving it from being destroyed by the whirlpool.
events.significance: The appearance of Island Whales serves as a crucial turning point and creates an emotional callback to Laboon, setting up one of the episode's most heartwarming moments.

events.title: Luffy and Brook Mistake Whales for Laboon
events.description: Upon seeing the Island Whales, both Luffy and Brook initially believe they're seeing Laboon, the whale they encountered at Reverse Mountain. They quickly realize it's a pod of similar Island Whales, not Laboon himself who remains at the Grand Line entrance.
events.significance: This emotional moment reinforces Brook's ongoing promise to reunite with Laboon after completing the journey around the world, a key character motivation that will eventually pay off.

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy initially thinking he sees Laboon

quotes.text: It's not Laboon... but they're Island Whales just like him!
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Brook realizing these are Laboon's species

events.title: Brook Plays Binks' Sake for the Island Whales
events.description: Brook begins playing Binks' Sake, the song he and the Rumbar Pirates used to play for Laboon 50 years ago. The Island Whales respond positively to the music, calming down and beginning to help the Straw Hats.
events.significance: This deeply emotional moment connects Brook's past with the Rumbar Pirates to the present, showing how music transcends time and species. It demonstrates that Laboon's species universally responds to this song, and reinforces Brook's connection to his promise.

quotes.text: Let me play them a song... the same song we played for Laboon.
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Brook deciding to play Binks' Sake for the whales

events.title: Whales Carry the Sunny to the Surface
events.description: In response to Brook's music, one of the Island Whales allows the Thousand Sunny to ride on its back and carries the crew to the surface of the New World, safely delivering them from the underwater danger.
events.significance: The whales' assistance represents a blessing for the crew's journey into the New World, and demonstrates the power of music and kindness to create unexpected alliances.

events.title: Arrival in the New World
events.description: The Straw Hat Pirates emerge from the depths onto the surface of the New World. They witness the treacherous conditions: turbulent red seas that Sanji describes as 'a sea of flames' and Zoro describes as 'the entrance to hell.' Luffy declares it 'perfect.'
events.significance: This marks the official arrival of the Straw Hat Pirates into the New World, the second half of the Grand Line where the strongest pirates compete. This is a major milestone in their journey toward finding the One Piece.

quotes.speaker: Chopper
quotes.context: Chopper observing the New World's appearance

quotes.text: It's like a sea of flames.
quotes.speaker: Sanji

quotes.text: Looks like the entrance to hell.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro's assessment of the New World

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Luffy's enthusiastic response to the dangerous conditions

events.title: Marine Warships Spotted
events.description: As the Straw Hats arrive in the New World, they encounter several Marine warships in the stormy seas. This is an anime-original addition that sets up the following Z's Ambition Arc.
events.significance: This scene diverges from the manga and serves as a transition to the anime-original filler arc while demonstrating that the Marines are also active in the New World.

quotes.text: It's not a sea snake, it's a White Strom! A gigantic white whirlpool that appears without warning on the sea floor!
quotes.speaker: Robin
quotes.context: Warning the crew about the danger

quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Responding to the dangerous New World conditions

themes.description: The episode marks a major milestone in the Straw Hats' journey as they officially enter the New World, the second half of the Grand Line where the strongest pirates compete for the title of Pirate King.
themes.symbolism: The red sea and flames symbolize the dangerous, hellish nature of the challenges ahead, while Luffy's enthusiastic 'Perfect!' response shows his fearless optimism.

themes.description: Brook's interaction with the Island Whales reinforces his promise to reunite with Laboon. The power of Binks' Sake to connect across time and species emphasizes the enduring nature of promises and memories.
themes.symbolism: The song Binks' Sake represents the bonds that transcend death and time, connecting Brook's past with the Rumbar Pirates to his future reunion with Laboon.

themes.description: The episode showcases the crew's enhanced abilities after the two-year timeskip through demonstrations of new techniques like Zoro's 360 Pound Cannon and Usopp's Hokaku Boshi.
themes.symbolism: The deep-sea fishing competition represents the crew testing their new abilities in preparation for the greater challenges of the New World.

themes.description: The Island Whales' positive response to music demonstrates the universal language of kindness and music, showing how harmony with nature can save lives.
themes.symbolism: Brook's violin playing brings peace to massive creatures, showing that music and compassion can overcome even the most dangerous situations.

characterSpotlights.development: Brook's connection to Laboon is reinforced through his interaction with the Island Whales, reminding viewers of his promise and demonstrating how his music can save the crew.
keyActions: Plays Binks' Sake to calm the whales
Helps save the crew through his musical abilities
quotes: It's not Laboon... but they're Island Whales just like him!

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy's fearless enthusiasm for the New World's dangerous conditions shows his growth and readiness to face the strongest sea.
keyActions: Enthusiastically embraces the New World's challenges

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro demonstrates his significantly enhanced power with the 360 Pound Cannon, showing the results of training with Mihawk.
keyActions: Uses 360 Pound Cannon to kill giant fish
Comments on the New World's hellish appearance
quotes: Looks like the entrance to hell.

characterSpotlights.development: Nami demonstrates her enhanced weather abilities and strategic thinking during the White Strom crisis.
keyActions: Strategizes their escape from the White Strom
Coordinates the crew's response to danger

mangaDifferences.difference: The scene where Sanji and Brook attempt to peek on Nami bathing is extended in the anime compared to the manga.
The anime hides what Usopp was working on until the creation was finished, while the manga shows it earlier.
Luffy mentions going into Gear 2 in the anime, which he didn't do in the manga.
The anime adds a scene where Nami gets dressed after bathing and comments on the crew acting like fools.

Instead of arriving at the red sea of flames as shown in the manga, the anime version shows the Straw Hats emerging into a stormy sea and encountering Marine warships to set up the Z's Ambition filler arc.

trivia.fact: This is the final episode of both the Fish-Man Island Arc and the Fish-Man Island Saga, marking the end of a 52-episode arc that began with episode 523.
Episode 574 adapts chapters 654-655 of the manga, but diverges significantly at the end to set up the anime-original Z's Ambition Arc (episodes 575-578).
The episode features a significant callback to episodes 62-63 and the Thriller Bark arc (episodes 337-381) through the Island Whales and Laboon connection.
From episode 279 to episode 1070, One Piece episodes did not feature ending theme songs, instead using the time for extended openings. Episode 574 falls within this range.
The White Strom is described as resembling a dragon, foreshadowing future dragon encounters in the series.
This episode marks the first time the Straw Hat Pirates officially enter the New World as a complete crew after the two-year timeskip.
